Encouraging and establishing sentient beings to equally possess morality, hearing, giving, and wisdom, this is called a good person.
Why is it called a good person?

Because the good person spoken of here is free from unwholesome dharmas and accomplishes wholesome dharmas, and fully accomplishes the four establishments of mindfulness, four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five strengths, seven factors of enlightenment, and eightfold noble path, it is called a good person.
If one is able to draw near to, serve, respect, and make offerings to this good person as spoken of, this is called drawing near to a good person.
What is called listening to the true Dharma?

It means that the good person who is drawn near and made offerings to, in places that are not yet clear, makes them clear, and in places that are not yet enlightened, makes them enlightened. Using wisdom to thoroughly understand the profound and wonderful meanings of the phrases, he skillfully proclaims, establishes, and reveals them, and with innumerable approaches correctly reveals them, that suffering is truly suffering, accumulation is truly accumulation, cessation is truly cessation, and the path is truly the path.
What is meant by correctly revealing through innumerable approaches that suffering truly is suffering?

It means correctly revealing the suffering of birth, the suffering of old age, the suffering of sickness, the suffering of death, the suffering of encountering what is unpleasant, the suffering of separation from what is loved, the suffering of not obtaining what is sought, and in brief, the suffering of the five appropriated aggregates.
As a verse says:
The arising of the aggregates is suffering, birth and leaving home are also suffering,
Having been born there is the suffering of old age, the suffering of sickness and the suffering of death,
The arising of afflictions is suffering, having arisen abiding is also suffering,ğŸ”½Lacking discernment and remorse is suffering, lack of self-control and death is suffering,
Ignorant sentient beings suffer, increasing the suffering of the ká¹£atriyas,
Foolish people suffer in birth and death, suffering from wandering through many eons.
These are called correctly revealing through innumerable approaches that suffering truly is suffering.
What is meant by correctly revealing through innumerable approaches that the origin truly is the origin?

That is to say, it is the correct teaching that craving, craving for future existence, craving accompanied by joy, and craving for this and that joy, are the root cause of the suffering of the past, present, and future, the path, the means, the condition for birth, the arising of the cause, the arising of the cause of arising, and the arising of the cause of arising in the present life, and that the suffering after the dissolution of the body arises from this.
As a verse says:
Because of craving, one abandons the good doctor, the root of the boil, the vine of thirst,
And is not subdued in all ways, repeatedly experiencing various sufferings.
Just as a tree whose roots have not been pulled out will grow again even if cut down,
So long as the latent tendencies of craving have not been pulled out, one will repeatedly experience various sufferings.
Just as a poisoned arrow in the body will damage one's complexion and strength,
So long as there is craving within sentient beings, it will damage all their wholesome roots.
These are called the correct teachings through innumerable approaches that the collection is truly the collection.
What is meant by the correct teachings through innumerable approaches that cessation is truly cessation?

That is to say, it is the correct teaching of the above-mentioned craving, craving for future existence, craving accompanied by joy, and craving for this and that, which is completely abandoned, given up, rejected, exhausted, free from defilements, ceased, calmed, and extinguished. It is called a house, an island, a refuge, a place to go, without sorrow, without illness, without movement, without submersion, without burning, without heat, peaceful, tranquil, a good thing, auspicious, and nirvana.
As a verse says:
The ultimate fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, praised by the disciplined,

The cessation of suffering is the ultimate refuge, free from attachment and ultimately pure,
The ultimate truth, worthy of offerings, realized by wisdom and delighted by the noble ones.
Completely free from old age, sickness, and death, without sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress,
Subtle, difficult to see, boundless, the truth of cessation has no equal.
These are called the immeasurable approaches through which the true cessation is correctly revealed as cessation.
How is it that the immeasurable approaches correctly reveal the true path as the path?

It is correctly revealed that this path and practice can eliminate, abandon, exhaust, become free from attachment, cease, become tranquil, and completely disappear from the various sufferings of the past, present, and future.
What is this again?
It is the eightfold noble path:
Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.
As a verse says:
This is the one path of vigor, like a bird's path through the clear sky,
The practice of the Sage's concentration, proclaimed for the multitude.
Out of compassion, he teaches the one path, seeing the end of birth in the exhaustion of the path,
This path, in the flood, is able to cross, in the past, future, and present.
Able to ultimately subdue and calm, able to exhaust the flow of birth and death,
Able to penetrate the many realms, able to illuminate the path of the eye.

Revealing the path of vast wisdom, quickly attaining nirvana.
Out of compassion for all beings, turning the Dharma wheel that has not been heard before,
Guiding devas and humans, I bow my head to the one who has crossed the ocean of existence.
These are called correctly revealing the true path as the path through innumerable approaches.

If one delights in listening to, hearing, upholding, mastering, understanding, contemplating, investigating, examining, penetrating, touching, realizing, and realizing for oneself these expounded true teachings, in order to hear the Dharma, one has no difficulty traversing difficult and dangerous paths, borderland roads, or level roads;

In order to uphold them, one frequently uses the ear faculty to encounter the sounds of expounding the Dharma and gives rise to the supreme ear consciousness. This is called listening to and hearing the true Dharma.
What is called proper mental attention?
It means that after hearing the true Dharma from a virtuous person, one inwardly rejoices and leaps with delight, thinking:ğŸ”½How marvelous!

The Buddha's explanation of suffering is truly suffering, the Buddha's explanation of the origin of suffering is truly the origin of suffering, the Buddha's explanation of the cessation of suffering is truly the cessation of suffering, and the Buddha's explanation of the path is truly the path.

They rejoice and leap for joy, and thus draw in and gather in their minds, and with attention and intention, they carefully and correctly contemplate the profound and wondrous meaning of the phrases. This is called proper attention.
What is meant by practicing in accordance with the Dharma?

It means that after repeatedly contemplating and carefully observing the profound meaning with proper attention, one gives rise to the five superior wholesome dharmas born of renunciation and seclusion, namely faith, zeal, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom.

One cultivates and abides firmly in the five superior wholesome dharmas born of renunciation and seclusion within oneself, and cultivates them uninterruptedly with superior effort. This is called practicing in accordance with the Dharma.
By diligently practicing in accordance with the Dharma, one can enter the certainty of rightness and be born free from birth.
The reason one can enter the certainty of rightness and be born free from birth is because of diligently practicing in accordance with the Dharma.

Therefore, one is able to contemplate the profound and wondrous meaning by respectfully listening to the true Dharma.

If one is able to draw near and make offerings to good people, one will then hear the true Dharma. Having heard the true Dharma, one will then be able to contemplate the profound and wondrous meaning in accordance with principle. It is like the top of a mountain, when the heavens pour down rain continuously, first the streams are filled, the streams being filled, the small ditches are filled, the small ditches being filled, the large ditches are filled, the large ditches being filled, the small rivers are filled, the small rivers being filled, the large rivers are filled, the large rivers being filled, the great ocean is filled, the great ocean is thus gradually filled.

Having contemplated the profound and wondrous meaning in accordance with principle, one is then able to cultivate the practice of Dharma in accordance with Dharma. Having entered into the detachment from birth, one is then called one who has already given rise to the eight branches of the noble path, namely right view and so forth as explained above.
These four are called the factors for entering the stream.

Because of these four, one is able to attain, reach, and fulfill the stream of the noble path, and is able to touch, realize, and realize it, and is therefore called the factors for entering the stream.

Chapter 3, Part 1: The Purity of Realization, Part 1. At one time the Blessed One was dwelling in ÅšrÄvastÄ«, in the Jeta Grove, in AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park.
At that time the World-Honored One said to the assembly of bhiká¹£us:

If sentient beings have faith and listen to and accept your teachings, and are able to practice them, you should have compassion for them and skillfully encourage them to be established in the four kinds of purity of realization.
What are the four?
They are the purity of realization of the Buddha, the purity of realization of the Dharma, the purity of realization of the Saá¹…gha, and the precepts loved by the noble ones.
Why is it so?
The earth, water, fire, and wind elements can all be changed.
But if the noble disciples who have attained these four kinds of purity, there is no change.
Because these many-heard noble disciples have attained these four kinds of purity, it is impossible for them to fall into the hells, the animal realm, or the realm of hungry ghosts.

Therefore, if there are those who faithfully listen to and accept your teachings and are able to practice them, you should have compassion and skillfully encourage and establish them in the four kinds of purity.
What is the purity of the Buddha?
As the World-Honored One said:

This noble disciple recollects the Buddhas in this way: 'The World-Honored One is the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the World, Unsurpassed, Tamer of Men, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, BhagavÄn.'
As for the term this, it refers to this desire realm, or this world, or this JambudvÄ«pa.

Moreover, as for the term this, it refers to those who are born in this very place, the Buddha and his disciples, the sages, the seers, the wise ones, the well-tamed ones, the well-disciplined ones.

As for World-Honored One, it will be explained later.
As for TathÄgata, as the World-Honored One said:

As for Arhat, there are broadly two kinds of arhat natures:
The first is conditioned;
The second is unconditioned.
What is the conditioned nature of an arhat?

It refers to the attainment of that fruit and the attainment of its attainment, the faculties and powers of one beyond training, the morality of one beyond training, the wholesome roots of one beyond training, the ten dharmas of one beyond training and the various dharmas of one beyond training of that kind.
